titlestmt.titleproper: Greater Hartford Jewish Community Center Collection 0008.120.001
titlestmt.subtitle: JCC Collection
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Updated by G. Farr, Archivist

publicationstmt.publisher: Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-12-18T12:03-0500

repository.corpname: Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford

physdesc.extent: 18 standard size document boxes and 7 boxes of photographs

bioghist.p: The local "Y" groups, however, disbanded in the late 1930s. Concerned for local youth, B'nai B'rith proposed in 1938 the formation of a community center, but it was not until 1942 that a Jewish Center Association was organized. Under the sponsorship of the United Jewish Social Service and the Community Chest, recreational programs were provided on Vine Street.

In 1948, the Jewish Federation, which had been organized in 1945, purchased a building on Asylum Avenue for a Community Center. Initially the Center concentrated on youth recreation at the Center itself, but gradually it expanded to a summer camp and activities for adults of all ages. In 1959, with an expanding membership and the westward movement of the Jewish population, the Community Center began planning for a new home. The Jewish Community Center on Bloomfield Avenue, designed by internationally acclaimed architect Walter Gropius, was completed in 1962. A major building addition was added in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Photographs
scopecontent.p: The GHJCC photographs collection documents a wide variety of religious, social, recreational and cultural activities. Both adult and youth activities are included. Most of the photographs in this collection were taken during the 1980s.
Photos: Box 1: Camps: Keshet, Macabee, Moshava, Naomi, Reenah, Shalom, New Hartford
Note, in 1978, Camp Sholom moved from New Hartford to Windsor and changed its name to Camp Shalom.
